title: 112_s647
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Montana Mineral Conveyance Act". Congress finds that the Secretary of the Interior has conveyed mineral rights in large coal tracts near the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation, leading to substantial public revenues from energy developments in the surrounding areas. The energy resources near the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation generate significant public revenues for the State, helping address development impacts. However, the tribal community faces economic challenges and lacks access to these revenues. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe has limited sources of income. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe lacks access to public revenues from surrounding energy development, leading to economic challenges. In 2002, the Tribe sued the Secretary over proposed conveyances of Federal coal tracts to the State, citing violations of Federal laws and the trust responsibility to the Tribe. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe sued the Secretary in 2002 over proposed conveyances of Federal coal tracts, citing violations of Federal laws and the trust responsibility to the Tribe. Subsequently, the Tribe withdrew the suit with prejudice based on commitments that legislation, including funding to address coal development impacts, would be introduced with support from the State and others. The Tribe asserts it retains claims against. The Tribe asserts claims against the United States for failing to acquire mineral rights on Reservation land when it was expanded in 1900. If mineral rights conveyances are made under this Act, the Tribe will waive all legal claims. If mineral rights conveyances are carried out under this Act, the Tribe will waive all legal claims against the United States related to the longstanding loss of mineral rights on Reservation land. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Cheyenne tracts" refers to a 5,000-acre land located in the eastern portion of the State within the Reservation boundaries, depicted on a map dated April 7, 2010. The Cheyenne tracts consist of various sections of land in T. 2 S., R. 44 E., sec. 17, 19, T. 3 S., R. 44 E., sec. 5, 7, 9, 17, 19 with different lot divisions. The Federal tracts are unleased land outside the Reservation in the State, totaling around 5,000 acres. The Reservation consists of approximately 5,000 acres of land located in specific sections as depicted on the map entitled "Federal Coal Land Conveyance" dated March 18, 2011. The Reservation consists of approximately 5,000 acres of land located in specific sections as depicted on the map entitled "Federal Coal Land Conveyance" dated March 18, 2011. The Great Northern Properties include various sections such as T. 4 S., R. 44 E., sec. 2, T. 6 N., R. 27 E., sec. 4, sec. 8, sec. 10, sec. 14, and sec. 22. Great Northern Properties refers to a Delaware limited partnership and any successor owning coal or iron under the Cheyenne tracts. Reservation means the Northern Cheyenne Reservation. Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and State means the State of Montana. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, "State" refers to the State of Montana, and "Tribe" refers to the Northern Cheyenne Tribe. SEC. 4. MINERAL RIGHTS CONVEYANCES. Great Northern Properties will convey mineral interests to the Tribe, and in return, the Secretary will convey coal rights to Great Northern Properties. The mineral interests conveyed to the Tribe will be immune from state taxation. SEC. 5. TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF MINERAL CONVEYANCES. The Tribe waives legal claims in exchange for mineral conveyances. A formula for revenue sharing must be agreed upon for coal production from Federal tracts. Mineral conveyances must be completed. After satisfying conditions, mineral conveyances for Federal coal rights must be completed within 90 days of notification. If invalidated by a Federal court, mineral conveyances under section 4(a) can be rescinded. If a Federal district court invalidates any part of mineral conveyances under section 4(a), the Secretary or Great Northern Properties can rescind all mineral conveyances. This rescission would also revoke the Tribe's waiver under subsection (a). SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY FOR OTHER FEDERAL BENEFITS.

No benefits under this Act shall reduce or deny Federal services to the Tribe or its members based on their federally recognized status. 

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Appropriations necessary for this Act are authorized.
